para.sentence: Equations of the form \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{2}}=z^{n}w, if n=1,2,3,\ldots, are used in approximating solutions to differential equations with multiple turning points; see ยง2.8(v).

The general solution of (9.13.1) is given by w=z^{1/2}\mathscr{Z}_{p}\left(\zeta\right), where p=\frac{1}{n+2}, ,\zeta=\frac{2}{n+2}z^{(n+2)/2}=2pz^{1/(2p)}, , and \mathscr{Z}_{p} is any linear combination of the modified Bessel functions I_{p} and e^{p\pi\mathrm{i}}K_{p} (ยง10.25(ii)).

Swanson and Headley (1967) define independent solutions A_{n}\left(z\right) and B_{n}\left(z\right) of (9.13.1) by A_{n}\left(z\right)=(2p/\pi)\sin\left(p\pi\right)z^{1/2}K_{p}\left(\zeta\right), ,B_{n}\left(z\right)=(pz)^{1/2}\left(I_{-p}\left(\zeta\right)+I_{p}\left(\zeta \right)\right), , when z is real and positive, and by analytic continuation elsewhere.
(All solutions of (9.13.1) are entire functions of z.
) When n=1 , A_{n}\left(z\right) and B_{n}\left(z\right) become \mathrm{Ai}\left(z\right) and \mathrm{Bi}\left(z\right) , respectively.
Properties of A_{n}\left(z\right) and B_{n}\left(z\right) follow from the corresponding properties of the modified Bessel functions.
They include: A_{n}\left(0\right)=p^{1/2}B_{n}\left(0\right)=\frac{p^{1-p}}{\Gamma\left(1-p \right)},-A_{n}'\left(0\right)=p^{1/2}B_{n}'\left(0\right)=\frac{p^{p}}{\Gamma\left(p \right)}.

A_{n}\left(-z\right)=\begin{cases}pz^{1/2}\left(J_{-p}\left(\zeta\right)+J_{p} \left(\zeta\right)\right),&n\text{ odd},\\ p^{1/2}B_{n}\left(z\right),&n\text{ even},\end{cases} , B_{n}\left(-z\right)=\begin{cases}(pz)^{1/2}\left(J_{-p}\left(\zeta\right)-J_{ p}\left(\zeta\right)\right),&n\text{ odd},\\ p^{-1/2}A_{n}\left(z\right),&n\text{ even}.\end{cases } \mathscr{W}\left\{A_{n}\left(z\right),B_{n}\left(z\right)\right\}=\frac{2}{\pi }p^{1/2}\sin\left(p\pi\right).

As z\to\infty A_{n}\left(z\right)=\sqrt{\ifrac{p}{\pi}}\sin\left(p\pi\right)z^{-n/4}e^{- \zeta}\left(1+O\left(\zeta^{-1}\right)\right), if |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq 3p\pi-\delta, , A_{n}\left(-z\right)=\begin{cases}2\sqrt{p/\pi}\cos\left(\tfrac{1}{2}p\pi \right)z^{-n/4}\left(\cos\left(\zeta-\tfrac{1}{4}\pi\right)+e^{|\Im\zeta|}O \left(\zeta^{-1}\right)\right),&\text{$|\operatorname{ph}z|\leq 2p\pi-\delta$, $n$ odd},\\ \sqrt{p/\pi}z^{-n/4}e^{\zeta}\left(1+O\left(\zeta^{-1}\right)\right),&\text{$| \operatorname{ph}z|\leq p\pi-\delta$, $n$ even},\end{cases} , B_{n}\left(z\right)={\pi}^{-1/2}z^{-n/4}e^{\zeta}\left(1+O\left(\zeta^{-1} \right)\right), if |\operatorname{ph}z|\leq p\pi-\delta, , B_{n}\left(-z\right)=\begin{cases}-(\ifrac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}})\sin\left(\tfrac{1}{ 2}p\pi\right)z^{-n/4}\left(\sin\left(\zeta-\tfrac{1}{4}\pi\right)+e^{\left|\Im \zeta\right|}O\left(\zeta^{-1}\right)\right),&\left|\operatorname{ph}z\right| \leq 2p\pi-\delta,n\text{ odd},\\ (\ifrac{1}{\sqrt{\pi}})\sin\left(p\pi\right)z^{-n/4}e^{-\zeta}\left(1+O\left( \zeta^{-1}\right)\right),&\left|\operatorname{ph}z\right|\leq 3p\pi-\delta,n \text{ even}.\end{cases }

The distribution in \mathbb{C} and asymptotic properties of the zeros of A_{n}\left(z\right) , A_{n}'\left(z\right) , B_{n}\left(z\right) , and B_{n}'\left(z\right) are investigated inSwanson and Headley (1967) and Headley and Barwell (1975).
In Olver (1977a, 1978) a different normalization is used. In place of (9.13.1) we have \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}t}^{2}}=\tfrac{1}{4}m^{2}t^{m-2}w, where m=3,4,5,\ldots.
For realvariables the solutions of (9.13.13) are denoted by U_{m}(t) , U_{m}(-t) when m is even, and by V_{m}(t) , \overline{V}_{m}(t) when m is odd.

(The overbar has nothing to do with complex conjugates.)Their relations to the functions A_{n}\left(z\right) and B_{n}\left(z\right) are given by m=n+2=1/p, ,t=(\tfrac{1}{2}m)^{-2/m}z=\zeta^{2/m}, , \sqrt{2\pi}\left(\tfrac{1}{2}m\right)^{(m-1)/m}\csc\left(\ifrac{\pi}{m}\right) A_{n}\left(z\right)=\begin{cases}U_{m}(t),&m\text{ even},\\ V_{m}(t),&m\text{ odd},\end{cases} \sqrt{\pi}\left(\tfrac{1}{2}m\right)^{(m-2)/(2m)}\csc\left(\ifrac{\pi}{m} \right)B_{n}\left(z\right)=\begin{cases}U_{m}(-t),&m\text{ even},\\ \overline{V}_{m}(t),&m\text{ odd}.\end{cases }

Properties and graphs of U_{m}(t) , V_{m}(t) , \overline{V}_{m}(t) are included inOlver (1977a) together with properties and graphs of real solutions of the equation \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}t}^{2}}=-\tfrac{1}{4}m^{2}t^{m-2}w, if m even, which are denoted by W_{m}(t) , W_{m}(-t).
In \mathbb{C} , the solutions of (9.13.13) used in Olver (1978) are w=U_{m}(te^{-2j\pi i/m}), if j=0,\pm 1,\pm 2,\ldots.

The function on the right-hand side is recessive in the sector -(2j-1)\pi/m\leq\operatorname{ph}z\leq(2j+1)\pi/m , and is therefore an essential member of any numerically satisfactory pair of solutions in this region.
Another normalization of (9.13.17) is used inSmirnov (1960), given by \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}x}^{2}}+x^{\alpha}w=0, where \alpha>-2 and x>0.

Solutions are w=U_{1}(x,\alpha) , U_{2}(x,\alpha) , where U_{1}(x,\alpha)=\frac{1}{(\alpha+2)^{1/(\alpha+2)}}\*\Gamma\left(\frac{\alpha+ 1}{\alpha+2}\right)x^{1/2}J_{-1/(\alpha+2)}\left(\frac{2}{\alpha+2}x^{(\alpha+ 2)/2}\right), U_{2}(x,\alpha)=(\alpha+2)^{1/(\alpha+2)}\*\Gamma\left(\frac{\alpha+3}{\alpha+ 2}\right)x^{1/2}J_{1/(\alpha+2)}\left(\frac{2}{\alpha+2}x^{(\alpha+2)/2}\right), and J denotes the Bessel function (ยง10.2(ii)).

When \alpha is a positive integer the relation of these functions to W_{m}(t) , W_{m}(-t) is as follows: \alpha=m-2, ,x=(m/2)^{2/m}t, , U_{1}(x,\alpha)=\frac{\pi^{1/2}}{2^{(m+2)/(2m)}\Gamma\left(1/m\right)}\left(W_ {m}(t)+W_{m}(-t)\right), U_{2}(x,\alpha)=\frac{\pi^{1/2}m^{2/m}}{2^{(m+2)/(2m)}\Gamma\left(-1/m\right)} \left(W_{m}(t){-}W_{m}(-t)\right).
For properties of the zeros of the functions defined in this subsection seeLaforgia and Muldoon (1988) and references given therein.

Reid (1972) and Drazin and Reid (1981, Appendix) introduce the following contour integrals in constructing approximate solutions to theOrrโSommerfeld equation for fluid flow: A_{k}\left(z,p\right)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\mathscr{L}_{k}}t^{-p}\exp\left(zt -\tfrac{1}{3}t^{3}\right)\mathrm{d}t, if k=1,2,3, p\in\mathbb{C}, B_{0}\left(z,p\right)=\frac{1}{2\pi i}\int_{\mathscr{L}_{0}}t^{-p}\exp\left(zt -\tfrac{1}{3}t^{3}\right)\mathrm{d}t, if p=0,\pm 1,\pm 2,\ldots, B_{k}\left(z,p\right)=\int_{\mathscr{I}_{k}}t^{-p}\exp\left(zt-\tfrac{1}{3}t^{ 3}\right)\mathrm{d}t, if k=1,2,3, p=0,\pm 1,\pm 2,\ldots, with z\in\mathbb{C} in all cases.
The integration paths \mathscr{L}_{0} , \mathscr{L}_{1} , \mathscr{L}_{2} , \mathscr{L}_{3} are depicted in Figure 9.13.1.
\mathscr{I}_{1} , \mathscr{I}_{2} , \mathscr{I}_{3} are depicted in Figure 9.13.2.
When p is not an integer the branch of t^{-p} in (9.13.25) is usually chosen to be \exp\left(-p(\ln|t|+i\operatorname{ph}t)\right) with 0\leq\operatorname{ph}t<2\pi.

When p=0 A_{1}\left(z,0\right)=\mathrm{Ai}\left(z\right), A_{2}\left(z,0\right)=e^{2\pi i/3}\mathrm{Ai}\left(ze^{2\pi i/3}\right), ,A_{3}\left(z,0\right)=e^{-2\pi i/3}\mathrm{Ai}\left(ze^{-2\pi i/3}\right), , and B_{0}\left(z,0\right)=0, ,B_{1}\left(z,0\right)=\pi\mathrm{Hi}\left(z\right), .

Each of the functions A_{k}\left(z,p\right) and B_{k}\left(z,p\right) satisfies the differential equation \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{3}w}{{\mathrm{d}z}^{3}}-z\frac{\mathrm{d}w}{\mathrm{d}z}+( p-1)w=0, and the difference equation f(p-3)-zf(p-1)+(p-1)f(p)=0.
The A_{k}\left(z,p\right) are related by A_{2}\left(z,p\right)=e^{-2(p-1)\pi i/3}A_{1}\left(ze^{2\pi i/3},p\right), ,A_{3}\left(z,p\right)=e^{2(p-1)\pi i/3}A_{1}\left(ze^{-2\pi i/3},p\right), .

Connection formulas for the solutions of (9.13.31) include A_{1}\left(z,p\right)+A_{2}\left(z,p\right)+A_{3}\left(z,p\right)+B_{0}\left(z ,p\right)=0, B_{2}\left(z,p\right)-B_{3}\left(z,p\right)=2\pi iA_{1}\left(z,p\right), B_{3}\left(z,p\right)-B_{1}\left(z,p\right)=2\pi iA_{2}\left(z,p\right), B_{1}\left(z,p\right)-B_{2}\left(z,p\right)=2\pi iA_{3}\left(z,p\right).

Further properties of these functions, and also of similar contour integrals containing an additional factor (\ln t)^{q} , q=1,2,\ldots , in the integrand, are derived in Reid (1972),Drazin and Reid (1981, Appendix), and Baldwin (1985).
These properties include Wronskians, asymptotic expansions, and information on zeros.
For further generalizations via integral representations seeChin and Hedstrom (1978), Janson et al. (1993, ยง10), andKamimoto (1998).
